text: nice hoppy aroma,brown, light brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice soft harmonic light fruit hoppy finish.

Bottle @ Voldby Tasting. Pours black with a offwhite head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, hops, citrus, peach, some catspiss notes aswell. Flavor is malts, coffee, dark chocolate, rich hoppy, peach and grapefruit. Medium body, soft carbonation, lasting bitter finish. Really nice one. 080513

Bottle. Dark brown close to black with a medium sized good lacing light beige head. Aroma is pine, citrus, smoked sausage, light chocolate, light . Taste is medium sweet and light+ bitter. Medium body, oily/light creamy texture, soft carbonation. Pretty soft and smooth.

På flaske i Fanøgade med Slackermads. Kul sort med lys brun skum. Frisk humlet duft. Sødlig, humlet, let røg, lidt bitter. Frugtig.  En tør bitter eftersmag

Bottle @ Y.N.W.A Beershop, Kolding. Pours black with a creamy head and lacings. Roast and a massive amount of fresh hops. Pine and grapefruit. Crisp and really fresh. Soft and smooth. Delicious.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 250413.
Black with beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and spices. Flavour with fruit, coffee and liqourice

500ml bottle. Pours a black colour, tan head which slowly diminishes leaving lots of lacing and aroma of pine & citrus resin hop, roast coffee. Taste is a juicy sweet fruity roast malt and dry pine resin grapefruit citrus hop bitterness with some earthy coffee notes. Smooth mouth feel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, lingering warming dry bitter finish. Nicely balanced and very drinkable black IPA.

Appearance: Black color with a small tan head that leaves a some lacing.Aroma: Dark malt, coffee, chocolate, grape hoppy and fruity.Palate: Medium plus body. Moderate sweet and a rich bitterness. Average carbonation.Taste: Grape hoppy, mild fruity, coffee and some chocolate. Overall impression: Lovely stuff! Had anyway a little bit higher hope at 7.5% abv. Personal stats: Bottle from Ninas Mini Market in Edinburgh, Scotland.

500mL bottle at Euston Tap, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma of dry toasted malts, some floral hops, and very dry notes. Flavour brings out very dry roasted / toasted malts, pungent piney hops, and dry bread. Very dry body, full of toasted malt and dry piney hops. Excellent black IPA - one of the best British beers out there.

Black. Aroma is fruity hops. Taste is a great and very sessional black ipa. Mellow malt and late tasty bitterness; fruitiness from hops. Nice bitter finish. Very good black ipa. Solid and drinkable.
Bottle from Slowbeer. Great taste. Aromas of chocolate and liquorice, hints of vanilla. Taste is sweet and bitter, with long length. Creamy palate. Black, with a frothy head.

Bottle at Babajan, April 2013.

Black with a creamy slightly tan head. Soft and nicely drinkable with light roasted malt, licorice, hops, grape. The finish was bitter.
120413. Bottle at Praha, Tampere. Pours dark mud like black with a nice head. Aroma dark malts, licorice. Dry palate. Not Bad.

Bottled at Babajan, Stockholm.  Completely black with rich off white head. Aroma of pear and sweaty grapefruit with notes of licorice. Mid sweet with near full body and well rounded mouthfeel. Licorice and minty grapefruit, some dark chocolate. Really bitter finish. Impressive with its flavour intensity and relaxed malt profile.

Cask (gravity) @ The 18th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2011, Reading, Berkshire England.Clear dark red brown colour with a average, frothy and open, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, moderate to heavy hoppy, grapefruit, orange - citrus, light licorice. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and modrate to heavy bitter with a average to long duration, hoppy bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120502]

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2014 500ml bottle (Angleterre, Helsinki) (6:5:7:4:14=3.6)
Nice roasty aroma. Mellow rich body. Smooth body, but carbonation a little higher than I like, swirls away though. Nice nuttiness. Not sure where this is aiming as its not a black IPA. I guess its a good hoppy stout though.Good balance between full stout roast and bitter hops. Aromatics not so extreme, barely fighting the other aspects, not a self-selling aroma at all. But still a nice beer.

Very similar to bottle, but a bit more aroma, both roast and pungent spicy hops. Taste matches that exactly. Covers 7.5% very well. Lovely hoppy stout. We did a comparison to Dark Arts, which wed previously given 3.7, and while that one smelt better, this clearly tasted better. Overall, the preference was here.
A nice floral bitterness with a roasted sweetness. A grapelike aftertaste. Dark brown in color with a light brown head.

500mL bottle. Pours pitch black with an off white head and an amazing fresh citric/berry aroma. Heavy malt influence in the flavour and I can also detect the alcohol and there is still a heavy hop presence. Very nice beer.

Bottle, 10C was a little too cold. Black with a modest but stable beige head. Aroma of grapefruit, chocolate, , red berries, gentle pine - enveloping rather than punchy. Creamy, low carbonation. Taste has sweet dark sugars and chocolate, citrus (grapefruit, leafy lemon) and berries. Bitterness is assertive then slowly fades to a point. Really good.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2016 Keg at The Hanging Bat and Andrew Ushers, and bottle at home. Black body with a thin beige head. Light lacing. Aroma of raisin, charcoal, dark chocolate, caramel and fig. Flavour of blood orange, wood, ash, coffee and dark chocolate. Medium body with a spritzy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. An ashy, full flavoured Black IPA.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2014 March 2013 - Cold 500ml bottle.  Big thick foamy head lasts a few minutes.  Smells piney, fair bit of cat urine.  Taste is really interesting.  Initially like a floral IPA, then comes in the barley and coffee, finish is more barley and bitterness, aftertaste is dark chocolate.  Flavours are strong but balanced.  This is great.  Not miles away from top marks.  (4.1)
Nov 2014 - 330ml bottle, new branding. 2 months old.  Black, big foamy tan head, full lacing.  Aroma is hoppy with apple, pine, some ash, fruit salad sweets.  Body is medium, slightly foamy, low-ish carbonation.  Taste is ash, pine, woody bitterness, soft medicinal, salty finish.  Nice, but not quite up to where it was last time round.  (3.8)

Bottle, bought @ YNWA, Kolding. Pours deep black with a medium, creamy, beige head. Aroma is lovely, citrus, chocolate, light roasted, grapefruit. Medium to low carbonation, lovely dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has firm chestnut, hazelnuts, roasted, dark chocolate and a nice hoppiness. Grapefruit, pine, peach. Very firm bitterness in the finish.
@BBF12. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, flower, pine and grass. Flavour is roasted malt, pine grass and light flower.

50cl bottle, poured into a shaker. Quite dark regarding colour, foggy, with a generous off-white creamy head. Excellent appearance. Wonderful aroma, pretty intense: lots of resinous hops with hints of fruit. Love the taste, very IPA-like, with some nuts and dark chocolate notes (subtle). Mouthfeel is medium/creamy, good carbonation. Dry palate, but no too much. Thats, by far, the most hoppy dark beer Ive tried until date. Delicious!

Bottled. Pours dark brown with an orange glow and a medium sized tan head that leaves a good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, licorice, caramel, grapefruit,  citrus zest and piney notes. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry and nice bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft CO2. An excellent black IPA. ★★★★

Bottle. Black with an interesting hoppiness with malts in the background.Some delicate spiciness as well. Different and very very easy to drink.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2016 Bottle at bar. Dark brown color, beige head. Bitter taste with roasty malts, pine, citrus and floral hops. Roasty, malty finish with coffee. Great black IPA.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2015 on tap @ Euston Tap, London. Color: black beer with no carbonation and small white head, really dense beer. Smell : hops, spices, malt, caramel. Taste : caramel, malt, and hops. Aftertaste : dry bitterness and spices.

Ooohhh, this is good. Very, very, good. Nice hit of coins, cant place the mash though. Seems to be going well with Victorian crime nonsense. Black IPA, porters, stouts, they all remind me of Victorian London. I can smell my Stilton, its nearly ready.

Bottle. Pours black with thin tan head. Zesty tropical fruit (grapefruit, nectarine) and roasted malt dominate the nose. Taste is tropical fruit juice, pine resin, fruits of the forest, more dark chocolate and a hint of liqourice. Finish is roasty, with a lingering and bitter hop presence. Medium-bodied; smooth and oily mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Could have been a touch more carbonated, but a delicious beer nonetheless.
Really good beer. Could have had a bit more body to balance strong hoppiness, still really enjoyable.

Bottle at pikilinna, tampere. Black color with light brown head. Nice strong aroma of hops, malts, sweet, roasty. Full bodied taste of coffee, hops, roasty, fruits. Balanced ipa-stout mix. Hops staying in mouth quite long.

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2012. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt and hops with tropical fruit. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is bitterness. Overall a good beer.

Bottle-conditioned from Cotteridge Wines. Pours slightly effervescent with tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of sticky tropical fruits - mango and pineapple - and a bit of nectarine. Taste-wise the tropical fruits have a slightly more bitter than sweet flavour, finishing with roast malts, bitter and dry. Very nice. Cant taste the weight of alcohol at all but may be because my bottle was slightly on the cold side.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Smell of hops. Black with beige head. Highly bitter. Aroma of hops, also some herbs and spices to be noted. Flowers in aftertaste. Slightly oily, flat carbon.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; pours dark black with a thin beige head, pine hop in the aroma, has a big hop taste with a background of roast chocolate malts. Dry finish, this is really good.

From cask @ Borefts 2012. This is a deep brown one with a big-bubbly and sidesticking beige top. On the nose I get a soft chocolate tone, biscuits, some ripe old fruits and thats about it. Soft to flat on the carbonation an it has a mild oily mouthfeel. Fruity hoppy flavors. Not much roastiness in this one. Tastes more like a dry English style IPA juiced up and added a black color. Still, its quite tasty. 30.09.2012

On gravity at the Factoberfest, Tobacco Factory, Bristol September 2012. Near black with a slight, off-white head. Big aroma of citrus fruits, grassy hops, pine and a touch of sweetness. Flavour had plenty of dark fruits and tangerines, a hint of fruit cake and a dry, resinous finish. Excellent.

Cask @ BBF 2012. Dark brown with a small tan head. Fruity with hop notes.
Malt, fruit and hops. Medium to full body with a nice bitter finish.
500ml bottle Cotteridge Wines B30. Reminded me of Kernel brewery Black IPA.  Strong taste from dark malts and American hops. A good beer.
On Tap @ Borefts Bierfestival 2012/ The head is unrobust, the body black. The taste is mild, hoppy, a bit grassy, hoppy. Overall to grassy and in my opinion a bit to warm for this style. 9/8/9/9/-/9

text: Boreft Beer Festival 2012. Dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of orange peel, toffee and licorice. Sweet citrus and licorice flavour with a touch of alcohol.

My favorite beer of the few I tried from Buxton. Black pour with medium tan head. Aromas of resinous hops, light roast, and chalk, Taste is citrus fuely hops, pine resin, sweet malts, and some grain spice. Finished excellent with a full assortment of flavors left behind. Very long finish.

A black beer with a medium, creamy and beige head. Aroma is balanced, citrusfruits and liquirice. The Black IPA is one of the few wholly American beer styles, but now everyone wants to get on the bandwagon. Buxton Imperial Black IPA is impressive not only for the fact its a British take on the style, but an excellent example of what can be done with it. Citrus, pine, light sweet maltiness and amazing drinkability make up the palate of this beer and they do it very well.

I received a 500ml bottle from Buxton Brewery (thanks, Mike!). I poured it into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Opaque black body with just the faintest hints of ruby red edges. Forms a creamy khaki-colored head which laces and retains very well.

Smell: Big pine notes of sticky sap and resin, coupled with raw orange fruit and hints of candy.

Taste: Buxton Imperial Black IPA has everything Im looking for in a beer of the style, mostly in that its so well-balanced. Its very bitter, slightly sweet, slightly tart and slightly dry - yet all these components blend pretty much perfectly in this palate. 

It begins with a Guinness-like palate of light coffee and chocolate notes and some porter-like qualities I might compare to cough medicine. Through the middle comes a bold flavor of sticky pine bitterness, which eventually gives way to an orange juice-like taste and tartness. The end is a crescendo of all the flavors that came before it - almost exploding with flavor on the tongue. You wouldnt think these components would work so well together, but they actually do. Its a fantastic balance of hoppy bitterness and malty sweetness. I didnt get much roasty notes on it, though, but thats okay because the end result is a tasty, delectable beer.

Drinkability: The first thing I noticed even before the taste was just of smooth and comfortable the mouthfeel was. Its soft and velvety, but not thick or syrupy. Closer to that of a porter than a stout, but does have a bit of carbonation crispness of an IPA at the end (especially with that hop bite). It was difficult to drink this beer slow because it went down so easily and was so satisfying. Its surprisingly big at 7.5% ABV, but it has the energy level that comes with a beer of the size. I think Buxton Imperial Black IPA is a versatile brew as this would be complement a meal, cheese or act as a liquid dessert. Not a perfect beer, but pretty damn close.
